page.title: 19Industrial Archaeology
page.content: To the S.of Guisborough the N-facing slope of the NY Moors is covered by coniferous forest. But this hides the scars of 4 centuries of mining. Alum was 1st mined at Belmangate;this went on until made uneconomic by the chem. industry in 19th cent.Old clamps,in which alum shale was burnt over many months,still remain. This was a labour intensive but profitable ind. Next came jet mining,& spoil heaps can be seen among the trees. The last indus- try was ironstone mining.Old fragments of winch houses, rails,engine sheds, are visible. Iron was smelted on Tee- sside until recently; today all Clev- eland ironstone mining has ceased, as ores from Spain & Scandinavia are cheaper.Today Guisb. has little ind- ustry of any kind,& much unemployment; its industrial archaeology,however, provides important relics of the past.
